key_risks: Regulatory scrutiny and potential liabilities related to satellite end-of-life management
Significant financial losses and reliance on government contracts
Intense competition from terrestrial broadband providers and emerging satellite operators
Technological disruption from advancements in 5G and low-Earth orbit satellite networks
controversies: First-ever FCC fine for space debris due to failure to properly deorbit the EchoStar-7 satellite
Multiple legal disputes, including contract disagreements and allegations of unfair labor practices
environmental_issues: Space debris and sustainability concerns related to satellite launches
social_issues: Allegations of unfair labor practices and challenges in retaining customers
governance_issues: Dependence on government contracts and potential vulnerabilities to budget cuts or delays

sources.title: DISH fined for improper de-orbit of EchoStar-7 satellite
sources.snippet: The FCC stated that DISH relocated its direct broadcast service EchoStar-7 satellite at the end-of-mission to a disposal orbit "well below the elevation required by the terms of its license" after launching it in 2002 and that the company's action "could pose orbital debris concerns."

sources.title: FCC Fines Dish $150,000 for Failed Deorbit - Via Satellite
sources.snippet: The FCC took its first space debris enforcement action on Monday, fining Dish Network $150,000 for failure to properly deorbit its EchoStar-7 satellite. Dish admitted liability as part of the settlement. The EchoStar-7 was launched in February 2002 and entered service later that year.
